module.p:
seas crodh cattle stand up –
Bha Calum sgìth a’ coiseachd air a’ mhonadh, ach mu dheireadh ràinig e mullach na beinne. [...] Bha latha briagha ann agus bha a’ ghrian a’ deàrrsadh. [...] Bha an crodh blàth le teas na gréine agus bha iad ’nan seasamh anns na lochan beaga a bha an siud ’s an seo air feadh a’ mhonaidh.
Malcolm was tired walking on the moor, but at last he reached the top of the mountain. [...] It was a beautiful day and the sun was shining. [...] The cattle were warm with the heat of the sun and they were standing in the little lakes which were here and there throughout the moor. td. 146

seas ... aig dorus ... stands up at a door –
Sheas Màiri aig an dorus.
Mary stood (up) at the door. td. 47

seas ... aig uinneig ... stands up at a window –
An do sheas Màiri aig an uinneig? Sheas.
Did Mary stand (up) at the window? Yes, she did. td. 47–8

seas ... aig bòrd ... stands up at a table –
Seas aig a’ bhòrd!
Stand (up) at the window! td. 237
An do sheas e aig a’ bhòrd? Sheas.
Did he stand (up) at the window? Yes, he did. td. 237

seas ... ann an loch ... stands in a lake –
Bha Calum sgìth a’ coiseachd air a’ mhonadh, ach mu dheireadh ràinig e mullach na beinne. [...] Bha latha briagha ann agus bha a’ ghrian a’ deàrrsadh. [...] Bha an crodh blàth le teas na gréine agus bha iad ’nan seasamh anns na lochan beaga a bha an siud ’s an seo air feadh a’ mhonaidh.
Malcolm was tired walking on the moor, but at last he reached the top of the mountain. [...] It was a beautiful day and the sun was shining. [...] The cattle were warm with the heat of the sun and they were standing in the little lakes which were here and there throughout the moor. td. 146

éirich ... ’na s[h]easamh ... rises up –
Bha Calum sgìth a’ coiseachd air a’ mhonadh, ach mu dheireadh ràinig e mullach na beinne. Bha càrn chlach air mullach na beinne. Chuir Calum clach air a’ chàrn agus shuidh e ri taobh a’ chùirn a’ leigeil analach. [...] An ceann greise dh’éirich Calum ’na sheasamh agus thearnaich e a’ bheinn air a shocair.
Malcolm was tired walking on the moor, but at last he reached the top of the mountain. There was a cairn of stones on the top of the mountain. Calum put a stone onto the cairn and he sat down beside the cairn having a rest. [...] After a while Malcolm rose up and he descended the mountain leisurely. td. 146
